htmlEmbed:
After hundreds of covid-19 deaths in state-run veterans homes, lawmakers press VA to adhere to scienceThe Washington Post7/8/2020

Rep. Chrissy Houlahan (D-Pa.) has sent a letter to the Veterans Health Administration, demanding more information about the use of anti-malarial drugs including hydroxychloroquine at veterans homes and whether the VA was actively involved in the unproven treatment.

BusinessArchivedRead

pb-md">Rep. Chrissy Houlahan (D-Pa.) <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/context/letter-from-rep-houlahan-to-veterans-health-administration/384b6cb7-ef13-4f95-bf72-ebda4fa197e7/?itid=lk_inline_manual_4" target=_blank>sent a letter late last month </a>to the Veterans Health Administration, demanding more information about the use of anti-malarial drugs including hydroxychloroquine at veterans homes and whether VA was actively involved in the unproven treatment. She cited the beleaguered <a href="https://www.dmva.pa.gov/paveteranshomes/SouthEasternVeteransCenter/Pages/default.aspx" target=_blank>Southeastern Veterans Center </a>in the suburbs of Philadelphia, which treated about 30 veterans and their spouses with hydroxychloroquine in April.</p></div></div><div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">I urge you to learn from this experience to ensure that our veterans, whether they are in VAs care or in state veterans homes, get the best possible care based on sound science, Houlahan, an Air Force veteran, wrote in the July 28 letter.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The push comes as lawmakers continue to probe patient care at state-run homes for veterans, which receive about $1 billion in federal funding annually.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="font--article-body font-copy hide-for-print ma-0 pb-md db italic interstitial"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/07/07/covid-cocktail-inside-pa-nursing-home-that-gave-some-veterans-hydroxychloroquine-even-without-covid-19-testing/?itid=lk_interstitial_manual_9">The 'covid cocktail': Inside the PA nursing home that gave some veterans hydroxychloroquine even without covid-19 testing</a></span></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">More than 700 residents in state veterans homes have died from covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus, according to a tally of state data by The Washington Post. Homes in Pennsylvania, Louisiana, Maryland, New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts have been hit particularly hard, reporting outbreaks in some facilities of 30 deaths or more.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The Southeastern Veterans Center has reported more than 40 deaths. As residents fell ill, doctors in the home began to administer hydroxychloroquine, touted by President Trump as a possible remedy for covid-19. The treatment has been <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/05/26/hydroxychloroquine-who-trump-study/?itid=lk_inline_manual_11" target=_blank>shown to trigger</a> heart problems and other serious side effects in covid-19 patients, and the Food and Drug Administration revoked an emergency-use authorization issued in late March.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The Post found the so-called covid cocktail at the Southeastern Veterans Center was administered to 11 residents who had not been tested for covid-19, as well as those with serious underlying health conditions.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The use of the drug outraged some local lawmakers, nurses at the center and the families of residents, who said the medication was given without proper oversight after weeks of breakdowns in infection control protocols at the 238-bed home.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">It is unclear whether other state-run homes for veterans administered the drug. Houlahan asked VA to provide that data; she has not yet received a response.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Teresa Boyd, the assistant undersecretary for health for clinical services at VA, said at a <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/07/30/house-lawmakers-probe-patient-care-hydroxychloroquine-use-state-homes-veterans/?itid=lk_inline_manual_17" target=_blank>House hearing</a> last week that the department provided no specific guidance on the treatment. Medications, she said, are frequently used off-label.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Lawmakers at the hearing demanded greater accountability. At the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/10/nyregion/new-jersey-military-veterans-home.html" target=_blank>New Jersey Veterans Home</a> at Paramus, about 80 residents and a caregiver have died since the pandemic began. At the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/in-a-veterans-home-hit-by-the-coronavirus-chronic-problems-aided-a-disaster/2020/05/23/1c52f950-9476-11ea-8107-acde2f7a8d6e_story.html?itid=lk_inline_manual_20" target=_blank>Massachusetts Soldiers Home</a> in Holyoke, an outbreak killed 76 residents and sickened more than 200 patients and staff. The Government Accountability Office found the home lacked staff and personal protective equipment and failed to enforce social distancing.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="font--article-body font-copy hide-for-print ma-0 pb-md db italic interstitial"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/07/21/inspection-finds-widespread-infection-control-failures-facility-that-dosed-veterans-with-hydroxychloroquine/?itid=lk_interstitial_manual_21">Inspection finds widespread infection-control failures at facility that gave veterans hydroxychloroquine</a></span></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The idea that you had homes anywhere in the country where we didnt do everything possible to protect our veterans is not just heartbreaking, but completely unacceptable, U.S. Rep Josh Gottheimer (D-N.J.), whose district is home to the facility in Paramus, told The Post.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Sen. Jon Tester (D-Mont.) said VA should increase its presence in state-run homes and look to the science when recommending or administering treatments for covid-19.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Were pushing to ensure VA can monitor and effectively mitigate outbreaks at state veterans homes, Tester, ranking member of the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee, said in a statement to The Post. And Ill be holding VA accountable in ensuring that any treatments for covid-19 are backed by scientific studies proven to work.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) also said she is pushing for proper care in state-run homes.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">We must protect the health and safety of veterans in State Veterans Homes and other long-term care facilities using accurate science and data, not President Trumps bogus claims about drugs that are unproven to treat COVID-19, Warren said in a statement.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Sens. Tester, Warren, Edward J. Markey (D-Mass.) and Robert Casey (D-Pa.) penned a letter to VA in May calling for an investigation into the quality of patient care and the departments oversight of state homes.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">In her <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/context/letter-from-rep-houlahan-to-veterans-health-administration/384b6cb7-ef13-4f95-bf72-ebda4fa197e7/?itid=lk_inline_manual_31" target=_blank>July letter</a>, Houlahan asked whether VA plans to provide guidance to state homes about the future use of diagnostics, therapeutics or vaccines, saying the department should learn from its experience with hydroxychloroquine</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">I do worry that were going to repeat that bad process on our most vulnerable veterans, she said. This population deserves honor and respect and care.</p></div><div class="mb-lg-mod hide-for-print" id="link-box"><div data-qa="content" class="linkbox-content"><h3 class="font-md font-bold font--headline offblack lh-md pb-xs" data-qa="linkbox-headline">Coronavirus impact on Americas nursing homes</h3><h4 class="gray-darkest font-xxs font-light font--subhead pb-sm" data-qa="linkbox-subheadline">The Washington Post is examining the deadly effects of the coronavirus on nursing home residents and workers</h4><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/business/nursing-home-covid-deaths-pandemic/" target="_blank"><b>51 lives:</b></a> Portraits of the pandemics tragic toll on U.S. nursing homes</p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/dc-md-va/2021/03/24/nursing-home-vaccine-visits/" target="_blank"><b>Reuniting:</b></a> With vaccinations, nursing home visits resume but are tinged with grief and fear</p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/nursing-home-skip-vaccine/2021/02/12/4d31d17a-6bfa-11eb-9f80-3d7646ce1bc0_story.html" target="_blank"><b>Perspective:</b></a> I work in a nursing home. At the \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/in-a-veterans-home-hit-by-the-coronavirus-chronic-problems-aided-a-disaster/2020/05/23/1c52f950-9476-11ea-8107-acde2f7a8d6e_story.html\" target=_blank\u003eMassachusetts Soldiers Home\u003c/a\u003e in Holyoke, an outbreak killed 76 residents and sickened more than 200 patients and staff. readabilityObject.title: After hundreds of covid-19 deaths in state-run veterans homes, lawmakers press VA to adhere to science
readabilityObject.content:
A U.S. congresswoman from Pennsylvania, riled by the experimental use of hydroxychloroquine in a nursing home for veterans in her home district, is among several lawmakers calling on the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs to adhere to science when providing recommendations on future coronavirus treatments or vaccines.

Rep. Chrissy Houlahan (D-Pa.) sent a letter late last month to the Veterans Health Administration, demanding more information about the use of anti-malarial drugs including hydroxychloroquine at veterans homes and whether VA was actively involved in the unproven treatment. She cited the beleaguered Southeastern Veterans Center in the suburbs of Philadelphia, which treated about 30 veterans and their spouses with hydroxychloroquine in April.

I urge you to learn from this experience to ensure that our veterans, whether they are in VAs care or in state veterans homes, get the best possible care based on sound science, Houlahan, an Air Force veteran, wrote in the July 28 letter.

The push comes as lawmakers continue to probe patient care at state-run homes for veterans, which receive about $1 billion in federal funding annually.

More than 700 residents in state veterans homes have died from covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus, according to a tally of state data by The Washington Post. Homes in Pennsylvania, Louisiana, Maryland, New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts have been hit particularly hard, reporting outbreaks in some facilities of 30 deaths or more.

The Southeastern Veterans Center has reported more than 40 deaths. As residents fell ill, doctors in the home began to administer hydroxychloroquine, touted by President Trump as a possible remedy for covid-19. The treatment has been shown to trigger heart problems and other serious side effects in covid-19 patients, and the Food and Drug Administration revoked an emergency-use authorization issued in late March.

The Post found the so-called covid cocktail at the Southeastern Veterans Center was administered to 11 residents who had not been tested for covid-19, as well as those with serious underlying health conditions.

The use of the drug outraged some local lawmakers, nurses at the center and the families of residents, who said the medication was given without proper oversight after weeks of breakdowns in infection control protocols at the 238-bed home.

It is unclear whether other state-run homes for veterans administered the drug. Houlahan asked VA to provide that data; she has not yet received a response.

Teresa Boyd, the assistant undersecretary for health for clinical services at VA, said at a House hearing last week that the department provided no specific guidance on the treatment. Medications, she said, are frequently used off-label.

Lawmakers at the hearing demanded greater accountability. At the New Jersey Veterans Home at Paramus, about 80 residents and a caregiver have died since the pandemic began. At the Massachusetts Soldiers Home in Holyoke, an outbreak killed 76 residents and sickened more than 200 patients and staff. The Government Accountability Office found the home lacked staff and personal protective equipment and failed to enforce social distancing.

The idea that you had homes anywhere in the country where we didnt do everything possible to protect our veterans is not just heartbreaking, but completely unacceptable, U.S. Rep Josh Gottheimer (D-N.J.), whose district is home to the facility in Paramus, told The Post.

Sen. Jon Tester (D-Mont.) said VA should increase its presence in state-run homes and look to the science when recommending or administering treatments for covid-19.

Were pushing to ensure VA can monitor and effectively mitigate outbreaks at state veterans homes, Tester, ranking member of the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee, said in a statement to The Post. And Ill be holding VA accountable in ensuring that any treatments for covid-19 are backed by scientific studies proven to work.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) also said she is pushing for proper care in state-run homes.

We must protect the health and safety of veterans in State Veterans Homes and other long-term care facilities using accurate science and data, not President Trumps bogus claims about drugs that are unproven to treat COVID-19, Warren said in a statement.

Sens. Tester, Warren, Edward J. Markey (D-Mass.) and Robert Casey (D-Pa.) penned a letter to VA in May calling for an investigation into the quality of patient care and the departments oversight of state homes.

In her July letter, Houlahan asked whether VA plans to provide guidance to state homes about the future use of diagnostics, therapeutics or vaccines, saying the department should learn from its experience with hydroxychloroquine

I do worry that were going to repeat that bad process on our most vulnerable veterans, she said. This population deserves honor and respect and care.

Coronavirus impact on Americas nursing homes

The Washington Post is examining the deadly effects of the coronavirus on nursing home residents and workers

Perspective: I work in a nursing home. Heres why my colleagues are skipping the vaccine.

Vaccinations: Nursing home workers dont want the vaccine. What facilities are doing about it?

Regulations: CMS imposed few penalties at nursing homes despite promises of tough enforcement

Black nursing homes: Residents in majority-Black nursing homes suffer higher coronavirus death rates

Misusing federal money: Funding from the Cares Act went to nursing homes with deadly breakdowns in patient care

Violations: Nursing home chains violated federal standards meant to stop covid spread

Tell the Post: Do you work at a nursing home, or have a loved one at a long-term care facility?

readabilityObject.excerpt: Rep. Chrissy Houlahan (D-Pa.) has sent a letter to the Veterans Health Administration, demanding more information about the use of anti-malarial drugs including hydroxychloroquine at veterans homes and whether the VA was actively involved in the unproven treatment.
